Award.AbstractNarration: The principal investigator's proposed research has three parts. The first <br/>constructs representations using tools from topology and symplectic <br/>geometry, especially the theory of Goresky-Kottwitz-MacPherson, and <br/>extends those tools to larger classes of varieties. The second tackles <br/>algebraic and combinatorial projects that solve problems in the geometry <br/>of the associated varieties. This subject is often called modern Schubert <br/>calculus; specific projects include determining multiplication formulas <br/>inside the cohomology ring of flag varieties and Grassmannians. The third <br/>focuses on computational and enumerative geometric properties of <br/>varieties, such as Hessenberg varieties, that arise in areas of <br/>representation theory including the Langlands program. The projects will <br/>identify fundamental geometric properties of the varieties, like <br/>pure-dimensionality, that are critical to advances in representation <br/>theory.<br/><br/>Geometric representation theory builds algebraic structures called <br/>representations from geometric objects. This leads to deep insights <br/>connecting different mathematical disciplines, including algebra, <br/>geometry, combinatorics, and mathematical physics. Crucially, a geometric <br/>representation establishes a table of correspondences between geometry and <br/>algebra. On one hand, the table answers questions in representation <br/>theory via geometry; on the other, it answers questions in geometry using <br/>algebra and combinatorics. The proposal includes projects to foster <br/>student development at all levels and to provide mentoring for women and <br/>other underrepresented minorities in mathematics.
